Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Ontogeny of Complex Tool Use in Great Apes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the hallmarks of human evolution has been the creation and use of complex tools, but the specific mechanisms by which this behavioral adaptation developed are not fully understood. This doctoral dissertation project will investigate the roles of teaching and imitation, as well as sex differences in foraging tool use, in the development of tool skills in a wild chimpanzee population. Chimpanzees are our closest living relatives, and the study of their tool traditions provides unique insights into the evolutionary origins of human culture and technology. This project will also provide student field research and training opportunities and support great ape conservation efforts at the research site.

The specific goals of this project are to differentiate the social learning mechanisms involved in chimpanzees' acquisition of complex tool skills, quantify the impact of variable social learning opportunity, and evaluate competing hypotheses for sex differences in tool skill acquisition. Chimpanzees of the Goualougo Triangle, Republic of Congo, exhibit some of the most complex tool behavior among nonhumans, and this will be the first study to investigate how they learn these skills. Direct observations using focal and all-occurrence sampling will be conducted and supplemented by remote video footage of chimpanzee tool use. Both cross-sectional and longitudinal approaches will be employed to document the ontogeny of tool skills. Insights from this study will refine models of the evolution of material culture in the hominin lineage. Specifically, results will help to resolve debates about how social learning influences intraspecific behavioral diversity, illuminate how complex tool traditions are maintained among wild apes over generations, and clarify the ontogenetic origins of sexual differentiation in tool-assisted foraging among chimpanzees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The flourishing of technology, and the transmission of technical skills over generations, are hallmarks of human culture. Comparative research with chimpanzees can help us better understand what contributed to the evolution of technology in the lineage of humans and other great apes. Chimpanzees in the Congo Basin exhibit some of the most complex tool behaviors documented outside of humans. These apes combine different tools in sequence to gather insects and honey, and they select particular plant species to make their tools. They also manufacture brush tips onto the ends of herb probes, a modification which improves the efficiency of these tools for gathering insects.

This study investigated the development of tool skills in chimpanzees of the Goualougo Triangle, Republic of Congo and examined how social learning influences skill development, particularly in the context of termite gathering. These chimpanzees acquire tool use skills over a period of many years, first learning to use fishing probes to extract termites and only later learning to manufacture these tools independently and to combine tools in sequence. This study also compared data from the Goualougo Triangle to data from Gombe, Tanzania, the longest running field study of chimpanzees. At Goualougo, termite-gathering behaviors are more complex, and in contrast to Gombe, older, skilled chimpanzees at Goualougo actively donate tools to infant and juveniles. These results suggest that more complex tool behaviors are associated with increased social facilitation and support the hypothesis that an increase in active social facilitation contributed to the elaboration of more complex technical behaviors over the course of human evolution.

This research is part of the longest-running behavioral study on chimpanzees using camera traps, and this dissertation is the first to use camera traps to carry out longitudinal research on the development of tool skills in chimpanzees. These remote video cameras also record a range of endangered animal taxa, and these data assist with the long-term monitoring of biodiversity in Central Africa. In association with this study, the co-PI mentored five undergraduate students at Washington University in Saint Louis, who gained firsthand experience conducting research. This research also provided professional training opportunities for Congolese research assistants and field staff. The co-PI assisted with English language training and collaborated to implement new handheld and remote video technologies and to use video data for demographic assessment and population monitoring of multiple chimpanzee communities.
